title: Hotel Overall Financial Statements and Restaurant Menu Pricing
headline: With this free online course, learn how to analyse hotel overall financial statements and set menu prices.
description: The hotel sector is a vital part of the broader service economy as it caters to consumers that require overnight lodging. However, hotels need to ensure profitability. This course delves into the hotel industry and explores key revenue tools such as profit and loss statements, revenue management, expense control reports and menu pricing at restaurants. Do you want to control expenses and maximise profit? So why wait? Start learning today.

courseDescription:
Profitability is a crucial aspect of any business. But how can we control the expenses and maximise profit in an industry? We can do this using financial statements and reports. This course will teach how to analyse and understand the hotel’s overall financial statements. At first, it describes the hotel operations and the cost structure. Then discover the divisions and main and secondary departments before diving into the financial statements. The ‘Uniform System of Accounting for Lodging Industries’ prescribes the overall financial statements. This course outlines the fundamentals of accounting concepts like ‘accruals’, ‘allocation of expenses’ and ‘prepayments’. But how can we manage the revenue in a hotel? We discuss the key revenue terms regarding the quantity, the segmentation for revenue of the rooms division and the food and beverage branch of the hotel.

Next, this course will explain the standard templates for the hotel profit and loss statements. How can we evaluate the performance and the profitability of the hotel? We can do this using horizontal, vertical and ratio analysis. You will go through examples of horizontal, vertical and combined analyses and learn the limitations and critical concepts of ratio analysis. Next, we will examine the various operating and marketing reports before learning the classification of menu items that study profitability and popularity. Investigate the expenses and expense control reports. Explore labour cost, segregation and other components as service charges. You will also learn about productivity reports and ‘zero-base manning’. Finally, this course highlights cost management concepts.

The last part presents the five steps of Profit and Loss analysis and how to implement them. But how can you set the menu prices for the restaurant? This course will guide you through menu costing excel templates found in the resources section. You will learn to estimate the need to raise prices and the desired average spending of a guest. This course will be helpful to hotel managers who want to use the various financial statements to control expenses and maximise profit. It is also beneficial for food and beverage managers and individual restaurant owners who wish to set menu prices using data. Register today and become a financial wizard in the hotel industry.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to hotel operations and cost structure. You will learn about hotel financial reports and Profit & Loss statements, as prescribed by the Uniform System of Accounting for Lodging Industries. Also, you will be introduced to fundamentals of accounting concepts like accruals, allocation of expenses and prepayments.
topics: Fundamentals of Accounting Concepts and Accruals

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Key Revenue Terms Used in Hospitality
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the key revenue terms used in hospitality. You will learn about the key quantity and value drivers of rooms division revenue and its segmentation. Also, you will be introduced to the key quantity plus value drivers of food and beverage division revenue and its segmentation.
topics: Key Revenue Terms Used in Hospitality - Learning Outcomes
Rooms Division Key Revenue Terms on Quantity and Value
Food & Beverage Division Key Revenue Terms on Quantity and Value
Key Revenue Terms Used in Hospitality - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Standard Templates and Analysis Fundamentals Steps
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the standard templates of hotel profit & loss statements, as prescribed by USALI. You will learn about the Grand Profit & Loss Statement and the secondary ones. Also, you will be introduced to the three types of revenue analysis, like horizontal, vertical and ratio analysis.
topics: Standard Templates and Analysis Fundamentals Steps - Learning Outcomes
Standard Profit & Loss Templates Prescribed by USALI
Horizontal Analysis in Practice through Room Segment Report
Vertical Analysis Explained through Room Segment Report
Combined Analysis Simplified through Market Segment Report
Standard Templates and Analysis Fundamentals Steps - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the reports of revenue management analysis. You will learn about revenue by business, guest nationality, and benchmark reports. Also, you will be introduced to the booking lead period and lead pace reports. The upselling & upgrades reports are presented too moreover, you will learn about menu engineering.
topics: Revenue Management Analysis Reports - Learning Outcomes
Booking Lead Period and Booking Pace Reports
Revenue Management Analysis Reports - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to expenses and expense control reports. You will learn about the segregation of labour costs. Also, you will be introduced to the service charge and other components. The nature of expenses, productivity reports and zero-base manning are presented too moreover, you will learn about cost management ideas.
topics: Expenses and Expense Control Reports - Learning Outcomes
Expenses and Expense Control Reports - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the overall profit & loss analysis steps. You will learn about steps 1 and 2 of overall profit & loss analysis. Also, you will be introduced to step 3 of the analysis for the rooms division, and the food & beverage division.
topics: Overall Profit & Loss Analysis - Learning Outcomes
Overall Profit & Loss Analysis - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Setting Menu Prices for Restaurant Using Data
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to setting the menu prices for restaurants using data. You will learn about the reasons for pricing the menu, and the qualitative and quantitative factors. Also, you will be introduced to the key concepts and a menu template about menu costing. A template to see if you need to raise prices is presented too.
topics: Setting Menu Prices for Restaurant Using Data - Learning Outcomes
The Need to Price the Menu
Fundamentals of Determining Cost of Menu
Menu Costing Excel Template Explained in More Detail
Excel Template to Determine the Need to Increase Prices
Excel Template on Average Guest Spending as a Guide to Pricing
Setting Menu Prices for Restaurant Using Data - Lesson Summary

  • The following are some of the key points from this module:

    Hotel Operations and Cost Structure
    The hospitality operations and the cost structure includes the following:
    • Rooms division.
    • Food & beverage division.
    • Other operating departments.
    • Administration.
    • Sales & marketing.
    • Maintenance departement.
  • These divisions and main departments have a secondary structure to smaller individual departments.
  • Uniform System of Accounting for Lodging Industries (USALI)
    USALI provides standards for accounting and terms used in the industry.

  • Key Revenue Terms Used in Hospitality - Lesson Summary
  • The following are some of the key points from this module:

    Key Revenue Terms
    The key revenue terms are the following:
    • Quantitative (occupancy, covers, guests).
    • Value (average rate, Rev PAR, ave check).
    • Segmentation (rooms division, food & beverage division).
  • Rooms Division Revenue - Key Quantity Drivers
    The key drivers of room division, as about quantity, are the following:
    • Total number of rooms.
    • Rooms not available for sale (under renovation, out of order, not available).
    • Available/saleable rooms.
    • Room nights, occupied room nights, and occupancy %.
    • Complimentary rooms, permanent rooms.
  • Key Revenue Terms Used in Hospitality - Lesson Summary

    • Describe the hotel Profit & Loss statements, like the Grand Profit & Loss and the secondary ones.
    • Analyze the main parts of the Grand Profit & Loss statement.
    • Outline the three types of revenue analysis, which are horizontal, vertical and ratio analysis. 
    • Evaluate the results of the horizontal, the vertical and the combined analysis.
    • Discuss the limitations and the key things to remember for the ratio analysis.

  • Standard Templates and Analysis Fundamentals Steps - Lesson Summary
  • The following are some of the key points from this module:

    Hotel Profit & Loss (P & L) Statements as per International Standards of USALI
    The Profit & Loss Statements for hotels are prescribed by USALI are the Grand P & L, and the secondary P & L of the divisions.
    Main Parts of Grand P & L
    • Operating revenue.
    • Departmental expenses.
    • Undistributed operating expenses.
    • Gross operating profit.
    • Management fees.
    • Income before non-operating income and expenses.
    • Non-operating income and expenses.
    • Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization (EBITDA).
    • Replacement reserve.
    • EBITDA less replacement reserve.
  • Standard Templates and Analysis Fundamentals Steps - Lesson Summary
  • The following are some of the key points from this module:

    Hotel Profit & Loss (P & L) Statements as per International Standards of USALI

    Main Parts of Grand P & L
    • Operating revenue.
    • Departmental expenses.
    • Undistributed operating expenses.
    • Gross operating profit.
    • Management fees.
    • Income before non-operating income and expenses.
    • Non-operating income and expenses.
    • Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization (EBITDA).
    • Replacement reserve.
    • EBITDA less replacement reserve.
  • Standard Templates and Analysis Fundamentals Steps - Lesson Summary

    • Non-operating income and expenses.
    • Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization (EBITDA).
    • Replacement reserve.
    • EBITDA less replacement reserve.

  • Revenue Management Analysis Reports - Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Describe the operating and marketing reports of the revenue management analysis.
    • Explain the revenue by business source report and the guest nationality report.
    • Describe the concepts and reports of the booking lead period, booking lead pace, upselling and upgrades.
    • Evaluate the results of the market benchmark report by comparing the hotel with the competition set.
    • Evaluate the results of the menu engineering report.
    • Classify the menu items about their popularity and profitability, the reasons and the necessary actions. 
  • Operating and Marketing Reports, and Report about Revenue by Business Source

  • Expenses and Expense Control Reports - Lesson Summary
  • The following are some of the key points from this module:

    Labor Cost, Segregation to Management and Non-Management 
    • Management (directors, assistant directors, managers).
    • Non-management (supervisors, associates/employees).
  • Labor Cost, Segregation by Department on Non-Management 
    • Rooms division (front office, guest services, housekeeping, reservation, transportation, complimentary F & B).
    • Food & beverage division (F & B service, F & B kitchen).
    • Other operating departments (laundry, accounting & finance, security, general support, purchasing & store, human resources).
    • Sales & marketing services.
    • Maintenance.
  • Expenses and Expense Control Reports - Lesson Summary

  • Overall Profit & Loss Analysis - Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Define the Profit & Loss analysis steps.
    • Recognise the Profit & Loss analysis step 1, in the overall P & L statement.
    • List the Profit & Loss analysis steps 2 and 3 in the rooms division P & L and in the food & beverage P & L.
    • Discuss the key concepts and conclusions of Profit & Loss analysis.

  • Overall Profit & Loss Analysis - Lesson Summary
  • The following are some of the key points from this module:

    Profit & Loss Analysis Steps
    1. Understand the overall P & L to identify areas of concern.
    2. Drill down to marketing reports for revenue analysis.
    3. Drill to detailed P & L to narrow expense variances.
    4. Get more details of itemizes cause of unfavourable expenses.
    5. Plan action to remediate concerns. 
  • Profit & Loss Analysis Examples - key concepts
    • We compare the variance between this year and budget, and between this year and last year.
    • In the overall P & L statement, we focus on the departments that have a higher drop in revenue compared to the variance of total revenue.
  • Overall Profit & Loss Analysis - Lesson Summary

  • How to Set Menu Prices for Restaurant Using Data - Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Explain the reasons for pricing the menu.
    • Describe the quantitative and qualitative factors in pricing the menu.
    • Compute the cost of the menu, by using a menu costing template.
    • Estimate the need to raise prices, by using an excel template.
    • Solve how much an average guest should spend, by using an excel template.
    • Define the qualitative factors that can make the prices higher, the same, or lower than the competition.

  • Setting Menu Prices for Restaurant Using Data - Lesson Summary
  • The following are some of the key points from this module:

    Why We Need to Price the Menu
    The pricing of the menu is a science and art together. It is a key in the success of the restaurant because it can scare the customer if it is too high, and not let profit if it is too low. The price of the menu need to do the following:
    • Covers variable food cost, fixed cost, and also to make a decent profit to cover the investment.
    • Costumers must see the product as value for money.
    • The prices need to be updated, because the food cost may change, or because maybe there is a change in the competition.
  • Quantitative & Qualitative Factors in Pricing the Menu
    • Quantitative factors like the desired cost % of menu items, desired overall Gross Profit Ratio (GPR), overheads/fixed cost of the restaurant, desired Return On Investment (ROI).
    • Qualitative factors like the competition pricing, location of the restaurant, demand & supply of such concept, and guest perception of quality and value.
